properties.Comments: Noted a mixed flock of birds foraging in adjacent residential yards in small subdivision while driving.  I stopped temporarily to determine species composition.  I pointed the birds out to my son Ethan.
First list of the new year, overcast and breezy kept the bird activity down.

Montgomery CBC: Jackson Island loop, 36F to start the morning, light to no wind for the entire loop.  Probably the most bird activity we've had in recent memory with large flocks of waxwings, robins and other mixed species flocks.  One species only seen by Ira was a RSHA.

Set out to look for Purple Sandpiper.  Rain started shortly after we left and continued for most of the morning.  We were unable to search thoroughly for the sandpiper due to the weather.  Had one darker bird amongst the sanderlings and turnstones but no confirmation.

Another stop at Mosquito Flats looking for the Nutting's Flycatcher.  About 20 minutes another couple from Nevada came by looking for the Nutting's. They helped us look and were the first to spot the bird.  We had good looks as the bird flew back and forth on the cliff side of the road.  We had good views for about 15 - 20 minutes.  White neck, washing to yellow belly.  Brown head and dark tail.

The gate was locked and we talked to a birder that walked down for half and hour and still didn't make it to the lake.  She saw a Stellar's Jay and Pygmy Nuthatch but we didn't walk that far down.  We tried several trails and drove to the ski area and Summerhaven with virtually no more birds.  We even went back to Molina Basin and Overlook with no luck.
Walked to lake overlook with David Vander Pluym, Tim Schreckengost, Brandon Breen, and Michelle and Jennifer Tobin.  Our first view of the amazing swallow spectacle here!
Breakfast watching birds at feeders and while reading paper. Sunny and cool.
Dale and I trying to get life birds for grandsons visiting from NY. Photos of all birds, but Indigo Bunting and Northern Oriole.

Some of my friends were walking home when we all heard a Cerp sound comeing from a black bird with a red sholder  I imediatly threw down my back pack and got out my bird card and saw it was a red wiged black bird and not just one of them BUT FOUR!

Totals from pelagic trip on Grande out of San Diego. This portion of the total list is the traversing of the 30-Mile Bank in Los Angeles County from south to north. Highlight was finding the large flock of storm-petrels near the north end of the bank where we found them last year. Boat speed was approximately 8 knots. Conditions were fair and calm with a 3-5 foot swell.
With Linn Post. Next time, we take the truck. And water. And go first thing in the morning. It was hella hot.

BJ, Michaeleen, Peggy and I went on a search for the Dipper - and it came in, on schedule, at 5:30, with a friend, singing, cleaning a leaf in the water, and providing a mechanism for Peggy to get away from Allan, the young, lighthouse-obsessed christian from San Jose.
An amazing time here - sunny, bright, and birdy! My best trip here yet, part of Sequoia Audubon follow-up trip after eBird class. Migrant flock greeted us.

61F sunny, clear. I walked all of the cottonwood stands. This is private property. Permission to pass must be obtained from BOTH the land owner and the person who leases the land to grow row crops. As far as I know some of the cottonwood stands were planted by the rancher. Obviously the stand in the creek drainage is natural. The row crops are watered with drip and spray. Shade, water, and insects are all attractive to birds, much as an oasis in a desert. The oriole and bunting were feeding on some ripe vegetables on the ground.
Sitting at the dining table looking at my photos from the morning when I caught a glimpse of BLUE from the rose bush in front of the picture window:

New Years Resolution to bird Hanover Pond every week this year.  Want to have a good record of what uses the Pond and when.  I've had 85 species there over the last three years.  Can I get up to one hundred species for the pond?
Species observed white waiting in line to enter the White House for a tour. This was a complete checklist, although I did not have binoculars.
Finally found the whooping cranes.  Best birding day ever!

Bill Pranty and I birded Eagle Point and Pasco Palms Parks here this morning and had another great showing of migrants inlcuiding a male Golden-winged Warbler and a female Cerulean Warbler!  Also 2 alternate plumage Stilt Sandpipers and 5 Semipalmated Sandpipers were seen.

Observed while sitting in yard. A group of 38 Fish Crows, most calling, came out of the SW over the yard. By the time they reached the property line at least three American Crows called out from the SE corner of the yard and sallied out to intercept, chase, or join the Fish Crows. In All about eight flew out, though only three called positively as American. The group merged, and then disappeared to the north, with both species calling raucously. About three minutes later a group of six crows returned to the yard; only two of them called, both American. A minute later another crow, this one silent but presumably also American, returned. My general impression is that the Americans were exhibiting territorial defense, making sure to "escort" the Fish Crows out of their territory.

strike 2!  I tried to relocate the red-breasted nuthatch but failed....I checked where it was reported and then searched the patch of pines at the intersection of gulf city and cockroach bay road and the pines south of cockroach bay road.----The first "tornado" of tree swallows were seen along gulf city road.The flock numbered about 300

The winds were 20 to 30 mph as Tropical Storm Beryl was approaching the Glynn County coast.  There were a few bands of showers.  Most of the birds observed earlier were gone from this somewhate sheltered area.  The tide was suppose to be low, but because of the on shore winds, the water never left the marshes and there were no feeding areas open to the birds other than in the spoil area.  I was hoping to see some pelagic birds blown in from the ocean.  No such luck.
Joe Weissman & I parked at the end of 9th Street, walked half way out to the beach and immediately saw what we had just driven 6hrs for: A Snowy Owl in Georgia!

My first visit to the reserve, and I was quite impressed.  When this place grows up some more its going to be incredible, a real jewel for the city.  Note on the #'s: For the Coots and Mallards, I estimated, particularly for the former.  Everything else is exactly as I saw it.

At first it was very quiet.  As we got into the trees the birds were first heard then seen.  Most of the grassy areas have been mowed which is most of the area.  We saw 3 deer & 1 coyote.  13 Birds were not identified, they were either too far away or we were unable to figure out what they were.
Cloudy. Calm. ~40F. Searching unsuccessfully for Snowy Owls reported @ Clinton Lake. Ran into Jane Liggett and others searching for the owl as well.

Hobbled out trail to where pine trees are dispersed and back;  side trip down left-hand dirt road.  Sunny; 68F;  lite breeze.  Feet killing me.  Wearing clogs for this hike.  2 separate trucks zoomed down the road and back.  Joy-riding.
Crows were mobbing what looked like a great horned owl.  A few minutes later a GHO landed in a tree near us.  It was then chased away by 2 red-tailed hawks, one of which was in a dive.
yard. thought i heard a yellow-billed cuckoo calling singing "coo coo coo coo coo"

Stuck in traffic due to construction on the Sagamore Bridge, Ian and I decided to conduct a traveling count from the very slow-moving car through the open windows. It was actually a pretty effective survey method and we got two new birds for our Cape Cod Big Day! common Nighthawk and Ovenbird, the latter our 19th warbler of the day!
Still no shorebirds. Probably a pipit but not 100% sure not a horn lark.  Manny in car with me.  'Don't drive in the water grandpa'

Cliff and I chased this one.  There was a forest fire in Paradise in the Spring, and we had seen postings in the listserve, so went in search of the Black-Backed Woodpecker.  Took us about 2 hours, but we finally saw her
Walking into work, can't help but notice birds around me.
I was a guide for the Sax-Zim Bog Birding Festival. This particular observation includes every participant of the festival getting great looks at the Great Gray Owl.
University of Minnesota ornithology class field walk.
59 degrees; clear; wind 5.  Black Vultures seen at 50 feet and less.  Two were working over a fish at the base of the boat ramp while a dozen Turkey Vultures looked on longingly.
A quick stop to look for a Scissor-Tailed Flycatcher nest reported here.

RIDG (ridge site) banding with Megan Fylling and Tricia Rodriguez.  We caught the WISA, which was cool!  I extracted the CAHU from the net too, it was crazy to handle such a small bird!  It flew away fine though!

The best part of my observations today was watching 2 Black-capped Chickadees share the peanut feeder with the Downy's. This is the 1st time we had Chickadees during the winter!!! They have been here since early December. I hope they will stick around all year, or at least come back every winter and bring more of their friends!

Crazy migrant activity in our yard and by the end of our driveway prevented me from leaving for my actual walk until almost 1:00! Some of the warblers were singing, especially the parulas and the Pine Warblers.

Pre-storm storm birding with Jane prior to arrival of Hurricane Sandy.  NE winds 20 - 30 knots.  Visibility variable from excellent in morning to poor late in day with heavy mist.  Part of the day from Little Boar's Head, part of the day from Ragged Neck.  At least 1/2 the day with Len Medlock and Jason Lambert.

Beautiful--sun piercing through fog where we stood on beach, looking out at the cloud sitting over the ocean, fairly close to shore.  We were enjoying the expected loons and a couple of gannets when a chocolate brown bird flew by just above the water with a flight pattern and "carriage" very different from that of a gull.  A sooty shearwater(!), perhaps inspired by the fog bank to fly close to shore.

I am new to birding and saw some birds for the first time. It was on the trail that loops around Barbour Pond in Garret Mountain. I have pictures of all the birds listed and a few that I don't know what they are. Of course Sandhill crane was taken with a crummy cell phone, but I was close enough to observe the red spot on its head and the bustle of feathers at it's tail, so it was a --Sandhill Crane and not the Blue Heron that has been staying there.

It was a clear and sunny 38F early morning birding hike in Oatka today. The songs of many bird species greeted me as I exited my car. It certainly seemed like an early spring day! Titmice could be heard in a call and answer with other titmice in the park. Cardinals and chickadees joined in the chorus, too. As I took this all in, a Northern Mockingbird popped on top of a tree next to the parking lot, giving me an ideal photo-op in the rising sun's golden glow. A few steps down the dirt road produced a close-up of a Carolina Wren with a wavering call that I had not heard from this species before. The excitement died down after that and the usual inhabitants slowly checked in over the course of the remainder of the hike. Robins continued to be very active with flocks frequently moving across the sky.

On this very hot morning, we did a somewhat abbreviated tour of the restored area, led by Ranger Christina and accompanied by a contingent of Urban Park Ranger Fellows (welcome, all!).  Great to see "our" Osprey chicks looking well and being fed and protected (both an egret and Great Blue Heron were "escorted" from the nest area).  Another treat--close views of a skimmer working the creek.
Hurricane Sandy hadn't really gotten here, although winds had picked up and there was a light wind-blown rain throughout the walk.  It was getting dark as well.  Bird activity was slow.

Every year we have a pair of canadian geese nest here.  We have a large pond in our back yard.  Every year I watch them from the nest bulding to the time they teach the babies to fly and leave.  Its wonderful and I would like to learn more about these facinating birds.  I have many stories to tell from watching these birds every year.

There is a raptor flying around I can't ID.  It has a short squared tail like a falcon and has a high pitched voice like a merlin but not the same sound pattern.  It sounds sort of a cross between a killdeer and a ringed-billed gull.  It's been in the area now for about 3 days.
Heard great horned owl several times while walking dog this am. They tend to stay i wooded area along creek across from house.
Owling for Flammulated Owls: stopped. Listened, played tape, listened.  at scattered locations from forest boundary to west bay campground, also went up 3010 road about 1 mi. Many stops, NO owls.

I was on a telephoned conference and observed 2 Bald Eagles mating in a tree behind my house. 2nd party was on the phone listening to me awing over what I was seeing. The only camera I own is on my cell phone and they were too far up to see them clearly.

I was sitting in yard praying, but I did notice catbirds and watched them about a minute or so. One made the kind of mewing sound, the smaller seemed to be trying to make timid musical sounds. The I heard and saw the starling for quite awhile

This was my first visit to the area following "Superstorm Sandy" on October 29. The road to the refuge sustained severe damage, and access was on foot. There was also some damage to the coastal trails and much shoreline erosion. Following this date, entry into the refuge has been prohibited and fines have been threatened, to the consternation of the birders and photographers who love this important bird habitat.
This hawk flew into  my feeder trying to snag a small bird there.  It missed and then sat on my birdhouse post.
Happened to see a pair of pelicans flying over the lake, from second story window overlooking the lake.  First pelicans of the season in this area.

Came home from work. Live on 50 acres. Went to get chicken eggs and saw the chickens scramble and at that moment saw a large dark bird land in the pine tree next to chicken house. Got out of truck and realized it was Harris hawk!  The size looked to be female. Found a dead, partialy eaten chicken in corner of pin. No mistake about what it was. I was a Falconer in the late 70's and through most of the 80's. Lived in Arizona for a couple of years and flew a few Harris hawks then. Could not believe what I was seeing here in far North East Texas. Saw her twice this evening. Did not notice any jessies on her legs as if from a falconers lost bird. Hope to see here again tomorrow.Chickens are locked up now.

Aerial Warfare----That is pretty much what it looks like when you have a smaller bird diving down on a larger bird.  We flushed a Bald Eagle from its roost on the side of the river.  Then out of the blue here comes smaller bird and starts to harass the eagle.  It was an aerial spectacle.  We did not get a positive ID on the smaller bird but it was the size of a hawk or Crow----Of course the falcon and Bald Eagle were two of our better species of the day.  We also found Pileated Woodpeckers, Green Kingfisher, Prothonotary Warblers and lots of Red-Eyed Vireos to round out our list of 36 species.----We have a long list of people who helped with the survey today.  We had Joan Bishop, Lea and Duncan Charlton, Bruce and his son Eric, Glen Coleman, Roger Shaw, JT Stewart, Jim Burk, Ron Armbruster, Bob West, John Barr, and Dennis Breining.  Thanks to all for your help today.
Mostly trying to relocate the Red Fox Sparrow we saw here back in December, but not surprisingly, we didn't find it.

Rushed up to Ann Day's house to see the Red-Bellied Woodpecker that she first observed on the woodpile yesterday. Zero degrees and windy there, so I was glad it did not take long for the bird to make itself known!
My wife, daughter and two grand-daughters and I searched this roadside area looking for night herons.
Also saw sea lion trying to eat a sturgeon on the Columbia River, a deer, small green frog in grass, and turtles on logs--Wonderful place to see bitterns

I saw hundreds of grackles in a single huge flock. Also I saw my first Canada warbler!!! I'm hearing a Black-Billed Cuckoo all the time also. Also Red-Shouldered hawk are back from the north I never see them in the summer.

Arrived by myself and ran into Jim Edlhuber who was taking pictures of the Snowy Owl.  While we were watching the owl, I spotted a shorebird in the shallow water right in front of us. We got good looks at the bird through the scope and Jim got photos that he has posted on the internet through picasaweb.  I covered the area from the harbor north of the impoundment, the ponds, to the area near the ferry terminal.

I was out stargazing with a group of people and made sure to pay attention to the birds that were there. I talked to another person in the group who camped at the Maxwell Property over the weekend and he told me that they heard several barred and great-horned owls  calling.

Fellow birders should take a look at this area. This park has a nice new shelter that has plenty of space and keeps you dry from the elements like OCT 13. This area has developed into a large mudflat and is holding shorebirds from time to time(including a large group of dunlins a week back) but the diving ducks are spectacular, and it's only going to take a little time and effort to probably pick some sea ducks out of the rafts of divers, as I know some have been spotted in this area years prior. Also the Red-throated Loon was pretty awesome to see.
We are SO  enjoying the Red-breasted Nuthatch.  Never had one around like this.  It loves the peanut butter/rawpeanuts on a pinecone.
